revision.text:
{{BLP sources|date=July 2011}} {{Infobox comedian | name = Ryan Stout | image = | caption = | birth_name =Ryan Matthew Stout | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1982|09|30}} |birth_place=[[Cleveland]], [[Ohio]] | death_date = | origin = [[Ohio]], United States | instrument = | genre = Comedy | occupation = [[stand-up comedian]] and [[television host]] | active = 2001–present | label = }}
'''Ryan Matthew Stout''' (born September 30, 1982) is an American [[stand-up comedian]] and [[television host]].<ref name="Pullen">Pullen, Doug (2011) "[http://www.elpasotimes.com/living/ci_19570091 The life of Ryan: Comedian from El Paso finds his niche by poking fun where few dare]", "El Paso Times, December 18, 2011, retrieved 2013-05-21</ref>
==Early life== Stout was born in [[Cleveland]], [[Ohio]], grew up in [[El Paso, Texas]],<ref name="Murtagh" /> and graduated from [[J.M. Hanks High School]] in 2000.<ref name="Pullen" /> He attended The [[College of Santa Fe]] (now [[Santa Fe University of Art and Design]]) as a Theater Arts major (2000–2001), but left the school after his first year. He later enrolled at [[San Francisco State University]] as a Creative Writing major.<ref name="Pullen" /><ref name="Murtagh">Murtagh, Heather (2005) "[http://xpress.sfsu.edu/archives/arts/003124.html Comic Slow Dances With the Dark Side]", ''Golden Gate XPress'', March 17, 2005, retrieved 2011-07-11</ref>
Stout first performed stand-up on his seventeenth birthday at a high school talent show.<ref name="Pullen" /> He continued to perform, although only a handful of times, at various poetry open-mics while attending the College of Santa Fe. In June 2001 he moved to [[San Francisco, California]]<ref name="Pullen" /> where the comedy scene allowed him more frequent stage time. He ingrained himself there for the next few years, performing over three hundred shows each year.
He was one of the last residents of the [[San Francisco Comedy Condo]].
Ryan Stout was awarded the [[Eagle Scout (Boy Scouts of America)|Eagle Scout rank]] in 1997 and is a member of the [[National Eagle Scout Association]].
As of March 2006, he lives in [[Los Angeles]].<ref name="Pullen" /><ref name="AVclub" />
==Career== Ryan Stout is the winner of the 2005 Boston Comedy Festival.<ref name="Pullen" /><ref name="LaughFactory">The Laugh Factory (2013) "[http://www.laughfactory.com/RyanStout Ryan Stout Biography]", "LaughFactory.com, retrieved 2013-05-21</ref> He is also one of the few comedians to perform at both [[Home Box Office|HBO]]'s The Comedy Festival in [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]] and HBO's [[U.S. Comedy Arts Festival]] in [[Aspen, CO]].<ref name="LaughFactory" /> He made his television debut on [[Comedy Central]]'s [[Live at Gotham]] in 2007. That same year he filmed pilot episodes for two separate television shows for [[MTV]], "I.Q." and a remake of the hit show "[[Singled Out]]," co-hosted by, Miss USA 2006, [[Tara Conner]]. By the end of the year MTV had him hosting the talk show [[A Shot at Love: The Hangover]].<ref name="LaughFactory" /><ref name="MTVpress">MTV Press (2008) "[http://mtvpress.com/press/release/have_another_round_on_mtv_a_shot_at_love_2_with_tila_tequila Have Another Round on MTV… "A Shot at Love 2]", "MTV Press, April 03, 2008, retrieved 2013-05-21</ref><ref name="Hood">Hood, Micaela (2013) "[http://www.southflorida.com/events/sf-go-ryan-stout-improv-0651713-20130516,0,4793177.story Ryan Stout: Hecklers beware]", "SouthFlorida.com, May 16, 2013, retrieved 2013-05-21</ref> In early 2008, he hosted a special called [[MTV's Most Valuable Players]], went on to host [[MTV's Spring Break 2008]],<ref name="Pullen" /><ref name="Hood" /><ref name="Loeffler">Loeffler, William (2008) "[http://www.pittsburghlive.com/x/valleyindependent/teenscene/s_595445.html Ryan Stout suits up for outrageous stand-up comedy]", ''[[Tribune-Review]]'', October 30, 2008, retrieved 2011-07-11</ref> and hosted a series called [[MTV's Ranked]].<ref name="LaughFactory" /> Concurrent with his television work he continued doing stand-up throughout the United States and performed at the [[Just For Laughs]] International Comedy Festival in Montreal, Quebec, Canada.<ref name="LaughFactory" /> Hosting opportunities continued at MTV, including several more game show pilots and conducting reunion episodes of several of the network's reality shows. He also started making appearances on [[WGN America|WGN]]'s [[The Bob and Tom Show]] <ref name="LaughFactory" /> and [[E! Entertainment Television]]'s [[Chelsea Lately]].<ref name="Pullen" /><ref name="Hamilton">Hamilton, Jon (2011) "[http://community.brownpapertickets.com/wp/?p=197#more-197 Interview with Comedian Ryan Stout]", "Brown Paper Tickets, September, 2011, retrieved 2013-05-21</ref>
Most recently, his [[Comedy Central Presents]] half-hour stand-up special premiered on April 30, 2010 which earned him the #10 spot in Comedy Central's yearly [[Stand-up Showdown]] in 2011.<ref name="Hamilton" /> Later that year Stout made his late-night stand-up debut on [[Conan (talk show)|Conan]].<ref name="Stout Appears on Late Night Television">{{cite web|last=Stout|first=Ryan|title=Stout Appears on Conan O'Brien|url=http://teamcoco.com/content/comedian-ryan-stout-reveals-upside-stds|work=Late Night television|publisher=Teamco|accessdate=1 November 2011}}</ref>
His debut album ''[[Touché (Ryan Stout album)|Touché]]'' was released on December 6, 2011, on [[Comedy Central Records]].<ref name="Raubicheck">Raubicheck, Marie (2011) "[http://www.comedycentral.com/press/press_releases/2011/112111-ryan-stout-digital-cd.jhtml?print=true Comedy Central Records Releases Ryan Stout's Touche Debut Digital Album]", "Comedy Central Press Release, November 21, 2011, retrieved 2013-05-21</ref>
Ryan Stout was guest on The CTSM Jan 30th 2012.
On August 6, 2012, he appeared on [[WTF with Marc Maron|WTF]] with [[Marc Maron]].<ref name="AVclub">A.V. Club (2012) "[http://www.avclub.com/articles/episode-302-ryan-stout,83409/ WTF With Marc Maron Episode 302 - Ryan Stout]", "A.V. Club, August 6, 2012, retrieved 2013-05-21</ref>
He was featured as "The Announcer" in the "Crickets" music video for hip hop group [[Drop City Yacht Club]].<ref name="Lastfm">Last.fm (2013) "[http://www.last.fm/music/Drop+City+Yacht+Club]", "Last.fm, March 26, 2013, retrieved 2013-05-21</ref>
On January 27, 2016, he appeared on [[Comedy Central]]’s program [[@midnight]] with [[Chris Hardwick]] <ref name="@Midnight">@midnight (2016) "[http://www.cc.com/full-episodes/60gcsj/-midnight-with-chris-hardwick-wednesday--january-27--2016-season-3-ep-03055]", “@midnight, January 27, 2016, retrieved 2016-02-02</ref>
